repnme.cdata!:
Iraq - Emergency Community Infrastructure
            Rehabilitation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Emergency Community
            Infrastructure Rehabilitation Project for Iraq were as
            follows: outcomes were satisfactory, risk to development
            outcome was moderate, Bank performance was satisfactory, and
            Grantee performance was satisfactory. Some lessons learned
            included: the Banks role in capacity building and providing
            fiduciary monitoring agent (FMA) support to project
            management team (PMT) was also crucial, which helped to
            build up a dedicated and highly professional PMT. To
            maximize the project economic and social benefits, it is
            important to integrate the civil works development and
            rehabilitating irrigation and drainage infrastructure with
            improved agriculture and farming systems with farmer
            consultation for maximum synergies. The project results show
            that small local contractors are better in delivering
            development objectives in shortest possible time, with
            greater involvement of the local community and smaller
            duration also prevented issues arising from price change.
            Direct involvement of the beneficiaries in planning and
            implementation of operation and maintenance (O and M)
            systems, even at a later stage, creates a sense of ownership
            among farmers, which is instrumental in achieving
            sustainable water management. The grant equally emphasized
            creation of local employment which was a major concern due
            to rampant high unemployment. The project implementation and
            supervision experiences showed that the work of the FMA had
            been very important and beneficial to the achievement of the
            project outputs and outcomes. Despite an adverse operating
            environment, infrastructure rehabilitation activities can be
            implemented cost effectively.

10227424.trustfund:
TF053543-IRTF - COMMUNITY INFRASTRUCTURE
            PROJECT (BANK-EXECUTED),TF053546-IRTF - COMMUNITY INFRASTRUCTURE

repnme.cdata!:
Iraq - Emergency Community Infrastructure
            Rehabilitation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Emergency Community Infrastructure
            Rehabilitation Project for Iraq addresses current emergency
            needs for infrastructure rehabilitation at the community
            level and generates employment. This will cover the
            restoration of rural infrastructure using labor-intensive,
            small-scale civil works programs for water supply,
            sanitation, irrigation, and drainage infrastructure
            sub-projects. The project will identify and implement small
            water development sub-projects that are based on immediate
            infrastructure rehabilitation needs and priorities of
            communities, particularly those located in low-income areas.
            A first set of four subprojects has been identified and
            submitted to the Bank, and ten other sub-projects are being
            processed by the Ministry of Water Resources.

repnme.cdata!:
Iraq - Emergency Community Infrastructure
            Rehabilitation Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This environmental and social assessment
            concerning the implementation of the Emergency Community
            Infrastructure Rehabilitation Project, will guide, and
            support infrastructure subprojects, aiming to maintain
            regional balance, and equity among  ethnic religious groups,
            with consideration to the variations in population density.
            An environmental screening process shall determine the
            environmental category of each subproject, and whether it
            warrants an environmental assessment, or, an environmental
            management plan alone. Attached are samples of
            questionnaires to be conducted prior to subproject approval.
            It is specified cultural property, which includes monuments,
            works of art, or sites of significance points of view,
            defined as having archaeological, historical, architectural,
            or religious significance - will be avoided, and, should new
            finds occur the authorities should be notified, and steps
            shall be taken to preserve archaeological sites. Mitigation
            measures include good engineering design, to prevent further
            deterioration in the quantity, and quality of groundwater,
            and, in the absence of water supply networks, the project
            will assess feasible alternative/temporary options on a
            case-by-case basis, in compliance with the local ecology
            aspects. Wastewater must not enter streams without settling
            ponds, filters, or other processes. Co-ordination with
            stakeholders, and nongovernmental organizations (NGOs) must
            begin in the design phase itself. The natural landscape
            shall be preserved to the extent possible, through
            operations that prevent unnecessary destruction, or scarring
            of natural surroundings. The report also addresses potential
            resettlement, and compensation issues, including in
            particular, ethnic groups to ensure these groups
            participate, and benefit from the project implementation.
            Grievance mechanisms will be in place to assure compliance
            with these safeguards.
